nior Benedicke, Don Iohn, and all the gallants of the
towne are come to fetch you to Church.

speech.speaker: Hero.
speech.line: Helpe to dreſſe mee good coze, good Meg,
good Vrſula.

scene.stagedir: Enter Leonato, and the Conſtable, and the Headborough.

speech.speaker: Leonato.
speech.line: What would you with mee, honeſt neigh-
bour?

speech.speaker: Conſt.Dog.
speech.line: Mary ſir I would haue ſome confidence
with you, that decernes you nearely.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Briefe I pray you, for you ſee it is a buſie time
with me.

speech.speaker: Conſt.Dog.
speech.line: Mary this it is ſir.

speech.speaker: Headb.
speech.line: Yes in truth it is ſir.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: What is it my good friends?

speech.speaker: Con.Do.
speech.line: Goodman Verges ſir ſpeakes a little of the
matter, an old man ſir, and his wits are not ſo blunt, as
God helpe I would deſire they were, but infaith honeſt
as the ſkin betweene his browes.

speech.speaker: Head.
speech.line: Yes I thank God, I am as honeſt as any man li-
uing, that is an old man, and no honeſter then I.

speech.speaker: Con.Dog.
speech.line: Compariſons are odorous, palabras, neigh-
bour Verges.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Neighbours, you are tedious.

speech.speaker: Con.Dog.
speech.line: It pleaſes your worſhip to ſay ſo, but we are
the poore Dukes officers, but truely for mine owne part,
if I were as tedious as a King I could finde in my heart to
beſtow it all of your worſhip.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: All thy tediouſneſſe on me, ah?

speech.speaker: Conſt.Dog.
speech.line: Yea, and ‘twere a thouſand times more
than ‘tis, for I heare as good exclamation on your Wor-
ſhip as of any man in the Citie, and though I bee but a
poore man, I am glad to heare it.

speech.speaker: Head.
speech.line: And ſo am I.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: I would faine know what you haue to ſay.

speech.speaker: Head.
speech.line: Marry ſir our watch to night, excepting your
worſhips preſence, haue tane a couple of as arrant
knaues as any in Meſſina.

speech.speaker: Con.Dog.
speech.line: A good old man ſir, hee will be talking as
they ſay, when the age is in, the wit is out, God helpe vs,
it is a world to ſee: well ſaid yfaith neighbour Verges,
well, God’s a good man, and two men ride of a horſe,
one muſt ride behinde, an honeſt ſoule yfaith ſir, by my
troth he is, as euer broke bread, but God is to bee wor-
ſhipt, all men are not alike, alas good neighbour.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Indeed neighbour he comes too ſhort of you.

speech.speaker: Con.Do.
speech.line: Gifts that God giues.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: I muſt leaue you.

speech.speaker: Con.Dog.
speech.line: One word ſir, our watch ſir haue indeede
comprehended two aſpitious perſons, & we would haue
them this morning examined before your worſhip.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Take their examination your ſelfe, and bring it
me, I am now in great haſte, as may appeare vnto you.

speech.speaker: Conſt.
speech.line: It ſhall be ſuffigance.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Drinke ſome wine ere you goe: fare you well.

speech.speaker: Meſſenger.
speech.line: My Lord, they ſtay for you to giue your
daughter to her husband.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Ile wait vpon them, I am ready.

speech.speaker: Dogb.
speech.line: Goe good partner, goe get you to Francis Sea-
coale, bid him bring his pen and inkehorne to the Gaole:
we are now to examine thoſe men.

speech.speaker: Verges.
speech.line: And we muſt doe it wiſely.

speech.speaker: Dogb.
speech.line: Wee will ſpare for no witte I warrant you:
heere’s that ſhall driue ſome to a non-come, on-
ly get the learned writer to ſet downe our excommuni-
cation, and meet me at the Iaile.

scene.stagedir: Enter Prince, Baſtard, Leonato, Frier, Claudio, Benedicke, Hero, and Beatrice.

speech.speaker: Leonato.
speech.line: Come Frier Francis, be briefe, onely to the
plaine forme of marriage, and you ſhal recount their par-
ticular duties afterwards.

speech.speaker: Fran.
speech.line: You come hither, my Lord, to marry this Lady.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: To be married to her: Frier, you come to mar-
rie her.

speech.speaker: Frier.
speech.line: Lady, you come hither to be married to this
Count.

speech.speaker: Hero.
speech.line: I doe.

speech.speaker: Frier.
speech.line: If either of you know any inward impediment
why you ſhould not be conioyned, I charge you on your
ſoules to vtter it.

speech.speaker: Claud.
speech.line: Know you anie, Hero?

speech.speaker: Hero.
speech.line: None my Lord.

speech.speaker: Frier.
speech.line: Know you anie, Count?

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: I dare make his anſwer, None.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: O what men dare do! what men may do! what
men daily do!

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: How now! interieƈtions? why then, ſome be
of laughing, as ha, ha, he.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Stand thee by Frier, father, by your leaue,
Will you with free and vnconſtrained ſoule
Giue me this maid your daughter?

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: As freely ſonne as God did giue her me.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: And what haue I to giue you back, whoſe worth
May counterpoiſe this rich and precious gift?

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Nothing, vnleſſe you render her againe.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Sweet Prince, you learn me noble thankfulnes:
There Leonato, take her backe againe,
Giue not this rotten Orenge to your friend,
Shee’s but the ſigne and ſemblance of her honour:
Behold how like a maid ſhe bluſhes heere!
O what authoritie and ſhew of truth
Can cunning ſinne couer it ſelfe withall!
Comes not that bloud, as modeſt euidence,
To witneſſe ſimple Vertue? would you not ſweare
All you that ſee her, that ſhe were a maide,
By theſe exterior ſhewes? But ſhe is none:
She knowes the heat of a luxurious bed:
Her bluſh is guiltineſſe, not modeſtie.

speech.speaker: Leonato.
speech.line: What doe you meane, my Lord?

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Not to be married,
Not to knit my ſoule to an approued wanton.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Deere my Lord, if you in your owne proofe,
Haue vanquiſht the reſiſtance of her youth,
And made defeat of her virginitie.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: I know what you would ſay: if I haue knowne her,
You will ſay, ſhe did imbrace me as a husband,
And ſo extenuate the forehand ſinne: No Leonato,
I neuer tempted her with word too large,
But as a brother to his ſiſter, ſhewed
Baſhfull ſinceritie and comely loue.

speech.speaker: Hero.
speech.line: And ſeem’d I euer otherwiſe to you?

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Out on thee ſeeming, I will write againſt it,
You ſeeme to me as Diane in her Orbe,
As chaſte as is the budde ere it be blowne:
But you are more intemperate in your blood,
Than Venus, or thoſe pampred animalls,
That rage in ſauage ſenſualitie.

speech.speaker: Hero.
speech.line: Is my Lord well, that he doth ſpeake ſo wide?

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Sweete Prince, why ſpeake not you?

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: What ſhould I ſpeake?
I ſtand diſhonour’d that haue gone about,
To linke my deare friend to a common ſtale.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Are theſe things ſpoken, or doe I but dreame?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Sir, they are ſpoken, and theſe things are true.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: This lookes not like a nuptiall.

speech.speaker: Hero.
speech.line: True, O God!

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Leonato, ſtand I here?
Is this the Prince? is this the Princes brother?
Is this face Heroes? are our eies our owne?

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: All this is ſo, but what of this my Lord?

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Let me but moue one queſtion to your daughter,
And by that fatherly and kindly power,
That you haue in her, bid her anſwer truly.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: I charge thee doe, as thou art my childe.

speech.speaker: Hero.
speech.line: O God defend me how am I beſet,
What kinde of catechizing call you this?

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: To make you anſwer truly to your name.

speech.speaker: Hero.
speech.line: Is it not Hero? who can blot that name
With any iuſt reproach?

speech.speaker: Claud.
speech.line: Marry that can Hero,
Hero it ſelfe can blot out Heroes vertue.
What man was he, talkt with you yeſternight,
Out at your window betwixt twelue and one?
Now if you are a maid, anſwer to this.

speech.speaker: Hero.
speech.line: I talkt with no man at that howre my Lord.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Why then you are no maiden. Leonato,
I am ſorry you muſt heare: vpon mine honor,
My ſelfe, my brother, and this grieued Count
Did ſee her, heare her, at that howre laſt night,
Talke with a ruffian at her chamber window,
Who hath indeed moſt like a liberall villaine,
Confeſt the vile encounters they haue had
A thouſand times in ſecret.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: Fie, fie, they are not to be named my Lord,
Not to be ſpoken of,
There is not chaſtitie enough in language,
Without offence to vtter them: thus pretty Lady
I am ſorry for thy much miſgouernment.

speech.speaker: Claud.
speech.line: O Hero! what a Hero hadſt thou beene
If halfe thy outward graces had beene placed
About thy thoughts and counſailes of thy heart?
But fare thee well, moſt foule, moſt faire, farewell
Thou pure impiety, and impious puritie,
For thee Ile locke vp all the gates of Loue,
And on my eie-lids ſhall Conieƈture hang,
To turne all beauty into thoughts of harme,
And neuer ſhall it more be gracious.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Hath no mans dagger here a point for me?

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Why how now coſin, wherfore ſink you down?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Come, let vs go: theſe things come thus to light,
Smother her ſpirits vp.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: How doth the Lady?

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Dead I thinke, helpe vncle,
Hero, why Hero, Vncle, Signor Benedicke, Frier.

speech.speaker: Leonato.
speech.line: O Fate! take not away thy heauy hand,
Death is the faireſt couer for her ſhame
That may be wiſht for.

speech.speaker: Beatr.
speech.line: How now coſin Hero?

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Haue comfort Ladie.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Doſt thou looke vp?

speech.speaker: Frier.
speech.line: Yea, wherefore ſhould ſhe not?

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Wherfore? Why doth not euery earthly thing
Cry ſhame vpon her? Could ſhe heere denie
The ſtorie that is printed in her blood?
Do not liue Hero, do not ope thine eyes:
For did I thinke thou wouldſt not quickly die,
Thought I thy ſpirits were ſtronger then thy ſhames,
My ſelfe would on the reward of reproaches
Strike at thy life. Grieu’d I, I had but one?
Chid I, for that at frugal Natures frame?
O one too much by thee: why had I one?
Why euer was’t thou louelie in my eies?
Why had I not with charitable hand
Tooke vp a beggars iſſue at my gates,
Who ſmeered thus, and mir’d with infamie,
I might haue ſaid, no part of it is mine:
This ſhame deriues it ſelfe from vnknowne loines,
But mine, and mine I lou’d, and mine I prais’d,
And mine that I was proud on mine ſo much,
That I my ſelfe, was to my ſelfe not mine:
Valewing of her, why ſhe, O ſhe is falne
Into a pit of Inke, that the wide ſea
Hath drops too few to waſh her cleane againe,
And ſalt too little, which may ſeaſon giue
To her foule tainted fleſh.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Sir, ſir, be patient: for my part, I am ſo attired
in wonder, I know not what to ſay.

speech.speaker: Bea.
speech.line: O on my ſoule my coſin is belied.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Ladie, were you her bedfellow laſt night?

speech.speaker: Bea.
speech.line: No, truly: not although vntill laſt night,
I haue this tweluemonth bin her bedfellow.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Confirm’d, confirm’d, O that is ſtronger made
Which was before barr’d vp with ribs of iron.
Would the Princes lie, and Claudio lie,
Who lou’d her ſo, that ſpeaking of her foulneſſe,
Waſh’d it with teares? Hence from her, let her die.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Heare me a little, for I haue onely bene ſilent ſo
long, and giuen way vnto this courſe of fortune, by no-
ting of the Ladie, I haue markt.
A thouſand bluſhing apparitions,
To ſtart into her face, a thouſand innocent ſhames,
In Angel whiteneſſe beare away thoſe bluſhes,
And in her eie there hath appear’d a fire
To burne the errors that theſe Princes hold
Againſt her maiden truth. Call me a foole,
Truſt not my reading, nor my obſeruations,
Which with experimental ſeale doth warrant
The tenure of my booke: truſt not my age,
My reuerence, calling, nor diuinitie,
If this ſweet Ladie lye not guiltleſſe heere,
Vnder ſome biting error.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Friar, it cannot be:
Thou ſeeſt that all the Grace that ſhe hath left,
Is, that ſhe wil not adde to her damnation,
A ſinne of periury, ſhe not denies it:
Why ſeek’ſt thou then to couer with excuſe,
That which appeares in proper nakedneſſe?

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Ladie, what man is he you are accus’d of?

speech.speaker: Hero.
speech.line: They know that do accuſe me, I know none:
If I know more of any man aliue
Then that which maiden modeſtie doth warrant,
Let all my ſinnes lacke mercy. O my Father,
Proue you that any man with me conuerſt,
At houres vnmeete, or that I yeſternight
Maintain’d the change of words with any creature,
Refuſe me, hate me, torture me to death.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: There is ſome ſtrange miſpriſion in the Princes.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Two of them haue the verie bent of honor,
And if their wiſedomes be miſled in this:
The praƈtiſe of it liues in Iohn the baſtard,
Whose ſpirits toile in frame of villanies.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: I know not: if they ſpeake but truth of her,
Theſe hands ſhall teare her: If they wrong her honour,
The proudeſt of them ſhall wel heare of it.
Time hath not yet ſo dried this bloud of mine,
Nor age ſo eate vp my inuention,
Nor Fortune made ſuch hauocke of my meanes,
Nor my bad life reft me ſo much of friends,
But they ſhall finde, awak’d in ſuch a kinde,
Both ſtrength of limbe, and policie of minde,
Ability in meanes, and choiſe of friends,
To quit me of them throughly.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Pauſe awhile:
And let my counſell ſway you in this caſe,
Your daughter heere the Princeſſe (left for dead)
Let her awhile be ſecretly kept in,
And publiſh it, that ſhe is dead indeed:
Maintaine a mourning oſtentation,
And on your Families old monument,
Hang mournfull Epitaphes, and do all rites,
That appertaine vnto a buriall.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: What ſhall become of this? What wil this do?

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Marry this wel carried, ſhall on her behalfe,
Change ſlander to remorſe, that is ſome good,
But not for that dreame I on this ſtrange courſe,
But on this trauaile looke for greater birth:
She dying, as it muſt be ſo maintain’d,
Vpon the inſtant that ſhe was accus’d,
Shal be lamented, pittied, and excus’d
Of euery hearer: for it ſo fals out,
That what we haue, we prize not to the worth,
Whiles we enioy it; but being lack’d and loſt,
Why then we racke the value, then we finde
The vertue that poſſeſsion would not ſhew vs
Whiles it was ours, ſo will it fare with Claudio:
When he ſhal heare ſhe dyed vpon his words,
Th’ Idea of her life ſhal ſweetly creepe
Into his ſtudy of imagination.
And euery louely Organ of her life,
Shall come apparel’d in more precious habite:
More mouing delicate, and ful of life,
Into the eye and prospeƈt of his ſoule
Then when ſhe liu’d indeed: then ſhal he mourne,
If euer Loue had intereſt in his Liuer,
And wiſh he had not ſo accuſed her:
No, though he thought his accuſation true:
Let this be ſo, and doubt not but ſucceſſe
Wil faſhion the euent in better ſhape,
Then I can lay it downe in likelihood.
But if all ayme but this be leuelld falſe,
The ſuppoſition of the Ladies death,
Will quench the wonder of her infamie.
And if it ſort not well, you may conceale her
As beſt befits her wounded reputation,
In ſome recluſiue and religious life,
Out of all eyes, tongues, mindes and iniuries.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Signior Leonato, let the Frier aduiſe you,
And though you know my inwardneſſe and loue
Is very much vnto the Prince and Claudio.
Yet, by mine honor, I will deale in this,
As ſecretly and iuſtlie, as your ſoule
Should with your bodie.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Being that I flow in greefe,
The ſmalleſt twine may lead me.

speech.speaker: Frier.
speech.line: ‘Tis well conſented, preſently away,
For to ſtrange ſores, ſtrangely they ſtraine the cure,
Come Lady, die to liue, this wedding day
Perhaps is but prolong’d, haue patience & endure.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Lady Beatrice, haue you wept all this while?

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Yea, and I will weepe a while longer.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: I will not deſire that.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: You haue no reaſon, I doe it freely.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Surelie I do beleeue your fair coſin is wrong’d.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Ah, how much might the man deſerue of mee
that would right her!

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Is there any way to ſhew ſuch friendſhip?

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: A verie euen way, but no ſuch friend.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: May a man doe it?

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: It is a mans office, but not yours.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: I doe loue nothing in the world ſo well as you,
is not that ſtrange?

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: As ſtrange as the thing I know not, it were as
poſſible for me to ſay, I loued nothing ſo well as you, but
beleeue me not, and yet I lie not, I confeſſe nothing, nor
I deny nothing, I am ſorry for my couſin.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: By my ſword Beatrice thou lou’ſt me.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Doe not ſweare by it and eat it.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: I will ſweare by it that you loue mee, and I will
make him eat it that ſayes I loue not you.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Will you not eat your word?

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: With no ſawce that can be deuiſed to it, I pro-
teſt I loue thee.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Why then God forgiue me.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: What offence ſweet Beatrice?

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: You haue ſtayed me in a happy howre, I was a-
bout to proteſt I loued you.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: And doe it with all thy heart.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: I loue you with ſo much of my heart, that none
is left to proteſt.

speech.speaker: Bened.
speech.line: Come, bid me doe any thing for thee.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Kill Claudio.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Ha, not for the wide world.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: You kill me to denie, farewell.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Tarrie ſweet Beatrice.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: I am gone, though I am heere, there is no loue
in you, nay I pray you let me goe.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Beatrice.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Infaith I will goe.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Wee’ll be friends firſt.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: You dare eaſier be friends with mee, than fight
with mine enemy.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Is Claudio thine enemie?

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Is a not approued in the height a villaine, that
hath ſlandered, ſcorned, diſhonoured my kinſwoman? O
that I were a man! what, beare her in hand vntill they
come to take hands, and then with publike accuſation
vncouered ſlander, vnmittigated rancour? O God that I
were a man! I would eat his heart in the market-place.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Heare me Beatrice.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Talke with a man out at a window, a proper
ſaying.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Nay but Beatrice.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Sweet Hero, ſhe is wrong’d, ſhee is ſlandered,
ſhe is vndone.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Beat?

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Princes and Counties! ſurelie a Princely teſti-
monie, a goodly Count, Comfeƈt, a ſweet Gallant ſure-
lie, O that I were a man for his ſake! or that I had any
friend would be a man for my ſake! But manhood is mel-
ted into curſies, valour into complement, and men are
onelie turned into tongue, and trim ones too: he is now
as valiant as Hercules, that only tells a lie, and ſweares it:
I cannot be a man with wiſhing, therfore I will die a wo-
man with grieuing.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Tarry good Beatrice, by this hand I loue thee.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Vſe it for my loue ſome other way then ſwea-
ring by it.

speech.speaker: Bened.
speech.line: Thinke you in your ſoule the Count Claudio
hath wrong’d Hero?

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Yea, as ſure as I haue a thought, or a ſoule.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Enough, I am engagde, I will challenge him, I
will kiſſe your hand, and ſo leaue you: by this hand Clau-
dio ſhall render me a deere account: as you heare of me,
ſo thinke of me: goe comfort your cooſin, I muſt ſay ſhe
is dead, and ſo farewell.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Conſtables, Borachio, and the Towne Clerke in gownes.

speech.speaker: Keeper.
speech.line: Is our whole diſſembly appeard?

speech.speaker: Cowley.
speech.line: O a ſtoole and a cuſhion for the Sexton.

speech.speaker: Sexton.
speech.line: Which be the malefaƈtors?

speech.speaker: Andrew.
speech.line: Marry that am I, and my partner.

speech.speaker: Cowley.
speech.line: Nay that’s certaine, wee haue the exhibition
to examine.

speech.speaker: Sexton.
speech.line: But which are the offenders that are to be ex-
amined, let them come before maſter Conſtable.

speech.speaker: Kemp.
speech.line: Yea marry, let them come before mee, what is
your name, friend?

speech.speaker: Bor.
speech.line: Borachio.

speech.speaker: Kem.
speech.line: Pray write downe Borachio. Yours ſirra.

speech.speaker: Con.
speech.line: I am a Gentleman ſir, and my name is Conrade.

speech.speaker: Kee.
speech.line: Write downe Maſter gentleman Conrade: mai-
ſters, doe you ſerue God: maiſters, it is proued alreadie
that you are little better than falſe knaues, and it will goe
neere to be thought ſo ſhortly, how anſwer you for your
ſelues?

speech.speaker: Con.
speech.line: Marry ſir, we ſay we are none.

speech.speaker: Kemp.
speech.line: A maruellous witty fellow I aſſure you, but I
will goe about with him: come you hither ſirra, a word
in your eare ſir, I ſay to you, it is thought you are falſe
knaues.

speech.speaker: Bor.
speech.line: Sir, I ſay to you, we are none.

speech.speaker: Kemp.
speech.line: Well, ſtand aſide, ‘fore God they are both in
a tale: haue you writ downe that they are none?

speech.speaker: Sext.
speech.line: Maſter Conſtable, you goe not the way to ex-
amine, you muſt call forth the watch that are their ac-
cuſers.

speech.speaker: Kemp.
speech.line: Yea marry, that’s the efteſt way, let the watch
come forth: maſters, I charge you in the Princes name,
accuſe theſe men.

speech.speaker: Watch 1.
speech.line: This man ſaid ſir, that Don Iohn the Princes
brother was a villaine.

speech.speaker: Kemp.
speech.line: Write down, Prince Iohn a villaine: why this
is flat periurie, to call a Princes brother villaine.

speech.speaker: Bora.
speech.line: Maſter Conſtable.

speech.speaker: Kemp.
speech.line: Pray thee fellow peace, I do not like thy looke
I promiſe thee.

speech.speaker: Sexton.
speech.line: What heard you him ſay elſe?

speech.speaker: Watch 2.
speech.line: Mary that he had receiued a thouſand Du-
kates of Don Iohn, for accuſing the Lady Hero wrong-
fully.

speech.speaker: Kemp.
speech.line: Flat Burglarie as euer was committed.

speech.speaker: Conſt.
speech.line: Yea by th’ maſſe that it is.

speech.speaker: Sexton.
speech.line: What elſe fellow?

speech.speaker: Watch 1.
speech.line: And that Count Claudio did meane vpon his
words, to diſgrace Hero before the whole aſſembly,
and not marry her.

speech.speaker: Kemp.
speech.line: O villaine! thou wilt be condemn’d into euer-
laſting redemption for this.

speech.speaker: Sexton.
speech.line: What elſe?

speech.speaker: Watch.
speech.line: This is all.

speech.speaker: Sexton.
speech.line: And this is more maſters then you can deny,
Prince Iohn is this morning ſecretly ſtolne away: Hero
was in this manner accus’d, in this very manner refus’d,
and vpon the griefe of this ſodainely died: Maſter Con-
ſtable, let theſe men be bound, and brought to Leonato,
I will goe before, and ſhew him their examination.

speech.speaker: Conſt.
speech.line: Come, let them be opinion’d.

speech.speaker: Sex.
speech.line: Let them be in the hands of Coxcombe.

speech.speaker: Kem.
speech.line: Gods my life, where’s the Sexton? let him write
downe the Princes Officer Coxcombe: come, binde them
thou naughty varlet.

speech.speaker: Couley.
speech.line: Away, you are an aſſe, you are an aſſe.

speech.speaker: Kemp.
speech.line: Doſt thou not ſuſpeƈt my place? doſt thou not
ſuspeƈt my yeeres? O that hee were heere to write mee
downe an aſſe! but maſters, remember that I am an aſſe:
though it be not written down, yet forget not ý I am an
aſſe: No thou villaine, ý art full of piety as ſhall be prou’d
vpon thee by good witneſſe, I am a wiſe fellow, and
which is more, an officer, and which is more, a houſhoul-
der, and which is more, as pretty a peece of fleſh as any in
Meſſina, and one that knowes the Law, goe to, & a rich
fellow enough, goe to, and a fellow that hath had loſſes,
and one that hath two gownes, and euery thing hand-
some about him: bring him away: O that I had been writ
downe an aſſe!

speech.speaker: Brother.
speech.line: If you goe on thus, you will kill your ſelfe,
And ‘tis not wiſedome thus to ſecond griefe,
Againſt your ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: I pray thee ceaſe thy counſaile,
Which falls into mine eares as profitleſſe,
As water in a ſiue: giue not me counſaile,
Nor let no comfort delight mine eare,
But ſuch a one whoſe wrongs doth ſute with mine.
Bring me a father that ſo lou’d his childe,
Whoſe ioy of her is ouer-whelmed like mine,
And bid him ſpeake of patience,
Meaſure his woe the length and bredth of mine,
And let it anſwere euery ſtraine for ſtraine,
As thus for thus, and ſuch a griefe for ſuch,
In euery lineament, branch, ſhape, and forme:
If ſuch a one will ſmile and ſtroke his beard,
And ſorrow, wagge, crie hem, when he ſhould grone,
Patch griefe with prouerbs, make misfortune drunke,
With candle-waſters: bring him yet to me,
And I of him will gather patience:
But there is no ſuch man, for brother, men
Can counſaile, and ſpeake comfort to that griefe,
Which they themſelues not feele, but taſting it,
Their counſaile turnes to paſſion, which before,
Would giue preceptiall medicine to rage,
Fetter ſtrong madneſſe in a ſilken thred,
Charme ache with ayre, and agony with words,
No, no, ‘tis all mens office, to ſpeake patience
To thoſe that wring vnder the load of ſorrow:
But no mans vertue nor ſufficiencie
To be ſo morall, when he ſhall endure
The like himſelfe: therefore giue me no counſaile,
My griefs cry lowder then aduertiſement.

speech.speaker: Broth.
speech.line: Therein do men from children nothing differ.

speech.speaker: Leonato.
speech.line: I pray thee peace, I will be fleſh and bloud,
For there was neuer yet Philoſopher,
That could endure the tooth-ake patiently,
How euer they haue writ the ſtile of gods,
And made a puſh at chance and ſufferance.

speech.speaker: Brother.
speech.line: Yet bend not all the harme vpon your ſelfe,
Make thoſe that doe offend you, ſuffer too.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: There thou ſpeak’ſt reason, nay I will doe ſo,
My ſoule doth tell me, Hero is belied,
And that ſhall Claudio know, ſo ſhall the Prince,
And all of them that thus diſhonour her.

speech.speaker: Brot.
speech.line: Here comes the Prince and Claudio haſtily.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Good den, good den.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Good day to both of you.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Heare you my Lords?

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: We haue ſome haſte Leonato.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Some haſte my Lord! wel, fareyouwel my Lord,
Are you ſo haſty now? well, all is one.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Nay, do not quarrel with vs, good old man.

speech.speaker: Brot.
speech.line: If he could rite himſelfe with quarrelling,
Some of vs would lie low.

speech.speaker: Claud.
speech.line: Who wrongs him?

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Marry ý doſt wrong me, thou diſſembler, thou:
Nay, neuer lay thy hand vpon thy ſword,
I feare thee not.

speech.speaker: Claud.
speech.line: Marry beſhrew my hand,
If it ſhould giue your age ſuch cauſe of feare,
Infaith my hand meant nothing to my ſword.

speech.speaker: Leonato.
speech.line: Tuſh, tuſh, man, neuer fleere and ieſt at me,
I ſpeake not like a dotard, nor a foole,
As vnder priuiledge of age to bragge,
What I haue done being yong, or what would doe,
Were I not old, know Claudio to thy head,
Thou haſt ſo wrong’d my innocent childe and me,
That I am forc’d to lay my reuerence by,
And with grey haires and bruiſe of many daies,
Doe challenge thee to triall of a man,
I ſay thou haſt belied mine innocent childe.
Thy ſlander hath gone through and through her heart,
And ſhe lies buried with her anceſtors:
O in a tombe where neuer ſcandall ſlept,
Saue this of hers, fram’d by thy villanie.

speech.speaker: Claud.
speech.line: My villany?

speech.speaker: Leonato.
speech.line: Thine Claudio, thine I ſay.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: You ſay not right old man.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: My Lord, my Lord,
Ile proue it on his body if he dare,
Deſpight his nice fence, and his aƈtiue praƈtiſe,
His Maie of youth, and bloome of luſtihood.

speech.speaker: Claud.
speech.line: Away, I will not haue to do with you.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Canſt thou ſo daffe me? thou haſt kild my child,
If thou kilſt me, boy, thou ſhalt kill a man.

speech.speaker: Bro.
speech.line: He ſhall kill two of vs, and men indeed,
But that’s no matter, let him kill one firſt:
Win me and weare me, let him anſwere me,
Come follow me boy, come ſir boy, come follow me
Sir boy, ile whip you from your foyning fence,
Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Brother.

speech.speaker: Brot.
speech.line: Content your ſelf, God knows I lou’d my neece,
And ſhe is dead, ſlander’d to death by villaines,
That dare as well anſwer a man indeede,
As I dare take a ſerpent by the tongue.
Boyes, apes, braggarts, Iackes, milke-ſops.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Brother Anthony.

speech.speaker: Brot.
speech.line: Hold you content, what man? I know them, yea
And what they weigh, euen to the vtmoſt ſcruple,
Scambling, out-facing, faſhion-monging boyes,
That lye, and cog, and flout, depraue, and ſlander,
Goe antiquely, and ſhow outward hidiouſneſſe,
And ſpeake of halfe a dozen dang’rous words,
How they might hurt their enemies, if they durſt.
And this is all.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: But brother Anthonie.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Come, ‘tis no matter,
Do not you meddle, let me deale in this.

speech.speaker: Pri.
speech.line: Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience
My heart is ſorry for your daughters death:
But on my honour ſhe was charg’d with nothing
But what was true, and very full of proofe.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: My Lord, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: I will not heare you.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: No come brother, away, I will be heard.

speech.speaker: Bro.
speech.line: And ſhall, or ſome of vs will ſmart for it.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: See, ſee, here comes the man we went to ſeeke.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Now ſignior, what newes?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Good day my Lord.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Welcome ſignior, you are almoſt come to part
almoſt a fray.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Wee had likt to haue had our two noſes ſnapt
off with two old men without teeth.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Leonato and his brother, what think’ſt thou? had
wee fought, I doubt we ſhould haue beene too yong
for them.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: In a falſe quarrell there is no true valour, I came
to ſeeke you both.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: We haue beene vp and downe to ſeeke thee, for
we are high proofe melancholly, and would faine haue it
beaten away, wilt thou vſe thy wit?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: It is in my ſcabberd, ſhall I draw it?

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Doeſt thou weare thy wit by thy ſide?

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Neuer any did ſo, though verie many haue been
beſide their wit, I will bid thee drawe, as we do the min-
ſtrels, draw to pleaſure vs.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: As I am an honeſt man he lookes pale, art thou
ſicke, or angrie?

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: What, courage man: what though care kil’d a
cat, thou haſt mettle enough in thee to kill care.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Sir, I ſhall meete your wit in the careere, and
you charge it againſt me, I pray you chuſe another ſub-
ieƈt.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Nay then giue him another ſtaffe, this laſt was
broke croſſe.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: By this light, he changes more and more, I thinke
he be angrie indeede.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: If he be, he knowes how to turne his girdle.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Shall I ſpeake a word in your eare?

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: God bleſſe me from a challenge.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: You are a villaine, I ieſt not, I will make it good
how you dare, with what you dare, and when you dare:
do me right, or I will proteſt your cowardiſe: you haue
kill’d a ſweete Ladie, and her death ſhall fall heauie on
you, let me heare from you.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Well, I will meete you, ſo I may haue good
cheare.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: What, a feaſt, a feaſt?

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: I faith I thanke him, he hath bid me to a calues
head and a Capon, the which if I doe not carue moſt cu-
riouſly, ſay my knife’s naught, ſhall I not finde a wood-
cocke too?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Sir, your wit ambles well, it goes eaſily.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Ile tell thee how Beatrice prais’d thy wit the o-
ther day: I ſaid thou hadſt a fine wit: true ſaies ſhe, a fine
little one: no ſaid I, a great wit: right ſaies ſhee, a great
groſſe one: nay ſaid I, a good wit: iuſt ſaid ſhe, it hurts
no body: nay ſaid I, the gentleman is wiſe: certaine ſaid
ſhe, a wiſe gentleman: nay ſaid I, he hath the tongues:
that I beleeue ſaid ſhee, for hee ſwore a thing to me on
munday night, which he forſwore on tueſday morning:
there’s a double tongue, there’s two tongues: thus did
ſhee an howre together tranſ-ſhape thy particular ver-
tues, yet at laſt ſhe concluded with a ſigh, thou waſt the
propreſt man in Italie.

speech.speaker: Claud.
speech.line: For the which ſhe wept heartily, and ſaid ſhee
car’d not.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Yea that ſhe did, but yet for all that, and if ſhee
did not hate him deadlie, ſhee would loue him dearely,
the old mans daughter told vs all.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: All, all, and moreouer, God ſaw him when he
was hid in the garden.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: But when ſhall we ſet the ſauage Bulls hornes
on the ſenſible Benedicks head?

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Yea and text vnder-neath, heere dwells Bene-
dicke the married man.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Fare you well, Boy, you know my minde, I will
leaue you now to your goſſep-like humor, you breake
ieſts as braggards do their blades, which God be thank-
ed hurt not: my Lord, for your manie courteſies I thank
you, I muſt diſcontinue your companie, your brother
the Baſtard is fled from Meſſina: you haue among you,
kill’d a ſweet and innocent Ladie: for my Lord Lacke-
beard there, he and I ſhall meete, and till then peace be
with him.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: He is in earneſt.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: In moſt profound earneſt, and Ile warrant you,
for the loue of Beatrice.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: And hath challeng’d thee.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Moſt ſincerely.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: What a prettie thing man is, when he goes in his
doublet and hoſe, and leaues off his wit.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: He is then a Giant to an Ape, but then is an Ape
a Doƈtor to ſuch a man.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: But ſoft you, let me be, plucke vp my heart, and
be ſad, did he not ſay my brother was fled?

speech.speaker: Conſt.
speech.line: Come you ſir, if iuſtice cannot tame you, ſhee
ſhall nere weigh more reaſons in her ballance, nay, and
you be a curſing hypocrite once, you muſt be lookt to.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: How now, two of my brothers men bound? Bo-
rachio one.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Harken after their offence my Lord.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Officers, what offence haue theſe men done?

speech.speaker: Conſt.
speech.line: Marrie ſir, they haue committed falſe report,
moreouer they haue ſpoken vntruths, ſecondarily they
are ſlanders, ſixt and laſtly, they haue belyed a Ladie,
thirdly, they haue verified vniuſt things, and to conclude
they are lying knaues.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Firſt I aske thee what they haue done, thirdlie
I aske thee what’s their offence, ſixt and laſtlie why they
are committed, and to conclude, what you lay to their
charge.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Rightlie reaſoned, and in his owne diuiſion, and
by my troth there’s one meaning well ſuted.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Who haue you offended maſters, that you are
thus bound to your anſwer? this learned Conſtable is too
cunning to be vnderſtood, what’s your offence?

speech.speaker: Bor.
speech.line: Sweete Prince, let me go no farther to mine an-
ſwere: do you heare me, and let this Count kill mee: I
haue deceiued euen your verie eies: what your wiſe-
domes could not diſcouer, theſe ſhallow fooles haue
brought to light, who in the night ouerheard me con-
feſſing to this man, how Don Iohn your brother incenſed
me to ſlander the Ladie Hero, how you were brought
into the Orchard, and ſaw me court Margaret in Heroes
garments, how you disgrac’d her when you ſhould
marrie her: my villanie they haue vpon record, which
I had rather ſeale with my death, then repeate ouer to
my ſhame: the Ladie is dead vpon mine and my maſters
falſe accuſation: and briefelie, I deſire nothing but the
reward of a villaine.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Runs not this ſpeech like yron through your
bloud?

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: I haue drunke poiſon whiles he vtter’d it.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: But did my Brother ſet thee on to this?

speech.speaker: Bor.
speech.line: Yea, and paid me richly for the praƈtiſe of it.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: He is compos’d and fram’d of treacherie,
And fled he is vpon this villanie.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Sweet Hero, now thy image doth appeare
In the rare ſemblance that I lou’d it firſt.

speech.speaker: Conſt.
speech.line: Come, bring away the plaintiffes, by this time
our Sexton hath reformed Signior Leonato of the matter:
and maſters, do not forget to ſpecifie when time & place
ſhall ſerue, that I am an Aſſe.

speech.speaker: Con.2.
speech.line: Here, here comes maſter Signior Leonato, and
the Sexton too.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Which is the villaine? let me ſee his eies,
That when I note another man like him,
I may auoide him: which of theſe is he?

speech.speaker: Bor.
speech.line: If you would know your wronger, looke on me.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Art thou the ſlaue that with thy breath
haſt kild mine innocent childe?

speech.speaker: Bor.
speech.line: Yea, euen I alone.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: No, not ſo villaine, thou belieſt thy ſelfe,
Here ſtand a paire of honourable men,
A third is fled that had a hand in it:
I thanke you Princes for my daughters death,
Record it with your high and worthie deedes,
‘Twas brauely done, if you bethinke you of it.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: I know not how to pray your patience,
Yet I muſt ſpeake, chooſe your reuenge your ſelfe,
Impoſe me to what penance your inuention
Can lay vpon my ſinne, yet ſinn’d I not,
But in miſtaking.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: By my ſoule nor I,
And yet to ſatisfie this good old man,
I would bend vnder anie heauie waight,
That heele enioyne me to.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: I cannot bid you bid my daughter liue,
That were impoſſible, but I praie you both,
Poſſeſſe the people in Meſſina here,
How innocent ſhe died, and if your loue
Can labour aught in ſad inuention,
Hang her an epitaph vpon her toomb,
And ſing it to her bones, ſing it to night:
To morrow morning come you to my houſe,
And ſince you could not be my ſonne in law,
Be yet my Nephew: my brother hath a daughter,
Almoſt the copie of my childe that’s dead,
And ſhe alone is heire to both of vs,
Giue her the right you ſhould haue giu’n her coſin,
And ſo dies my reuenge.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: O noble ſir!
Your ouerkindneſſe doth wring teares from me,
I do embrace your offer, and diſpoſe
For henceforth of poore Claudio.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: To morrow then I will expeƈt your comming,
To night I take my leaue, this naughtie man
Shall face to face be brought to Margaret,
Who I beleeue was packt in all this wrong,
Hired to it by your brother.

speech.speaker: Bor.
speech.line: No by my ſoule ſhe was not,
Nor knew not what ſhe did when ſhe ſpoke to me,
But alwaies hath bin iuſt and vertuous,
In anie thing that I do know by her.

speech.speaker: Conſt.
speech.line: Moreouer ſir, which indeede is not vnder white
and black, this plaintiffe here, the offendour did call mee
aſſe, I beſeech you let it be remembred in his puniſh-
ment, and alſo the watch heard them talke of one Defor-
med, they ſay he weares a key in his eare and a lock hang-
ing by it, and borrowes monie in Gods name, the which
he hath vs’d ſo long, and neuer paied, that now men grow
hard-harted and will lend nothing for Gods ſake: praie
you examine him vpon that point.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: I thanke thee for thy care and honeſt paines.

speech.speaker: Conſt.
speech.line: Your worſhip ſpeakes like a moſt thankefull
and reuerend youth, and I praiſe God for you.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: There’s for thy paines.

speech.speaker: Conſt.
speech.line: God ſaue the foundation.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Goe, I diſcharge thee of thy priſoner, and I
thanke thee.

speech.speaker: Conſt.
speech.line: I leaue an arrant knaue with your worſhip,
which I beſeech your worſhip to correƈt your ſelfe, for
the example of others: God keepe your worſhip, I
wiſh your worſhip well, God reſtore you to health,
I humblie giue you leaue to depart, and if a mer-
rie meeting may be wiſht, God prohibite it: come
neighbour.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Vntill to morrow morning, Lords, farewell.

speech.speaker: Brot.
speech.line: Farewell my Lords, we looke for you to mor-
row.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: We will not faile.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: To night ile mourne with Hero.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Bring you theſe fellowes on, weel talke with
Margaret, how her acquaintance grew with this lewd
fellow.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Praie thee ſweete Miſtris Margaret, deſerue
well at my hands, by helping mee to the ſpeech of Bea-
trice.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Will you then write me a Sonnet in praiſe of
my beautie?

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: In ſo high a ſtile Margaret, that no man liuing
ſhall come ouer it, for in moſt comely truth thou deſer-
ueſt it.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: To haue no man come ouer me, why, ſhall I al-
waies keepe below ſtaires?

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Thy wit is as quicke as the grey-hounds mouth,
it catches.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: And yours, as blunt as the Fencers foiles, which
hit, but hurt not.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: A moſt manly wit Margaret, it will not hurt a
woman: and ſo I pray thee call Beatrice, I giue thee the
bucklers.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Giue vs the ſwords, wee haue bucklers of our
owne.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: If you vſe them Margaret, you muſt put in the
pikes with a vice, and they are dangerous weapons for
Maides.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Well, I will call Beatrice to you, who I thinke
hath legges.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: And therefore will come. The God of loue that
ſits aboue, and knowes me, and knowes me, how pitti-
full I deſerue. I meane in ſinging, but in louing, Lean-
der the good ſwimmer, Troilous the firſt imploier of
pandars, and a whole booke full of theſe quondam car-
pet-mongers, whoſe name yet runne ſmoothly in the e-
uen rode of a blanke verſe, why they were neuer ſo true-
ly turned ouer and ouer as my poore ſelfe in loue: mar-
rie I cannot ſhew it rime, I haue tried, I can finde out no
rime to Ladie but babie, an innocent rime: for ſcorne,
horne, a hard rime: for ſchoole foole, a babling rime:
verie ominous endings, no, I was not borne vnder a ri-
ming Plannet, for I cannot wooe in feſtiuall tearmes:
ſweete Beatrice would’ſt thou come when I cal’d
thee?

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Yea Signior, and depart when you bid me.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: O ſtay but till then.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Then, is ſpoken: fare you well now, and yet ere
I goe, let me goe with that I came, which is, with know-
ing what hath paſt betweene you and Claudio.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Onely foule words, and thereupon I will kiſſe
thee.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Foule words is but foule wind, and foule wind
is but foule breath, and foule breath is noiſome, there-
fore I will depart vnkiſt.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Thou haſt frighted the word out of his right
ſence, ſo forcible is thy wit, but I muſt tell thee plainely,
Claudio vndergoes my challenge, and either I muſt ſhort-
ly heare from him, or I will ſubſcribe him a coward, and
I pray thee now tell me, for which of my bad parts didſt
thou firſt fall in loue with me?

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: For them all together, which maintain’d ſo
politique a ſtate of euill, that they will not admit any
good part to intermingle with them: but for which of
my good parts did you firſt ſuffer loue for me?

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Suffer loue! a good epithite, I do ſuffer loue in-
deede, for I loue thee againſt my will.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: In ſpight of your heart I think, alas poore heart,
if you ſpight it for my ſake, I will ſpight it for yours, for
I will neuer loue that which my friend hates.

speech.speaker: Bened.
speech.line: Thou and I are too wiſe to wooe peacea-
blie.

speech.speaker: Bea.
speech.line: It appeares not in this confeſſion, there’s not one
wiſe man among twentie that will praiſe himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: An old, an old inſtance Beatrice, that liu’d in
the time of good neighbours, if a man doe not ereƈt in
this age his owne tombe ere he dies, hee ſhall liue no
longer in monuments, then the Bels ring, & the Widdow
weepes.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: And how long is that thinke you?

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Queſtion, why an hower in clamour and a quar-
ter in rhewme, therfore is it moſt expedient for the wiſe,
if Don worme (his conſcience) finde no impediment to
the contrarie, to be the trumpet of his owne vertues, as
I am to my ſelfe ſo much for praiſing my ſelfe, who I my
ſelfe will beare witneſſe is praiſe worthie, and now tell
me, how doth your coſin?

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Verie ill.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: And how doe you?

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Verie ill too.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Serue God, loue me, and mend, there will I leaue
you too, for here comes one in haſte.

speech.speaker: Vrſ.
speech.line: Madam, you muſt come to your Vncle, yon-
ders old coile at home, it is prooued my Ladie He-
ro hath bin falſelie accuſde, the Prince and Claudio
mightilie abuſde, and Don Iohn is the author of all, who
is fled and gone: will you come preſentlie?

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Will you go heare this newes Signior?

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: I will liue in thy heart, die in thy lap, and be bu-
ried in thy eies: and moreouer, I will goe with thee to
thy Vncles.

scene.stagedir: Enter Claudio, Prince, and three or foure with Tapers.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Is this the monument of Leonato?

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: It is my Lord. Epitaph.
Done to death by ſlanderous tongues,
Was the Hero that here lies:
Death in guerdon of her wrongs,
Giues her fame which neuer dies:
So the life that dyed with ſhame,
Liues in death with glorious fame.
Hang thou there vpon the tombe,
Praiſing her when I am dombe.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Now muſick ſound & ſing your ſolemn hymne
Pardon goddeſſe of the night,
Thoſe that ſlew thy virgin knight,
For the which with ſongs of woe,
Round about her tombe they goe:
Midnight aſſiſt our mone, helpe vs to ſigh and grone.
Heauily, heauily.
Graues yawne and yeelde your dead,
Till death be vttered,
Heauenly, heauenly.

speech.speaker: Lo.
speech.line: Now vnto thy bones good night, yeerely will I do this right.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Good morrow maſters, put your Torches out,
The wolues haue preied, and looke, the gentle day
Before the wheeles of Phœbus, round about
Dapples the drowſie Eaſt with ſpots of grey:
Thanks to you all, and leaue vs, fare you well.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Good morrow maſters, each his ſeuerall way.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Come let vs hence, and put on other weedes,
And then to Leonatoes we will goe.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: And Hymen now with luckier iſſue ſpeeds,
Then this for whom we rendred vp this woe.

scene.stagedir: Enter Leonato, Bene. Marg. Vrſula, old man, Frier, Hero.

speech.speaker: Frier.
speech.line: Did I not tell you ſhe was innocent?

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: So are the Prince and Claudio who accus’d her,
Vpon the errour that you heard debated:
But Margaret was in ſome fault for this,
Although againſt her will as it appeares,
In the true courſe of all the queſtion.

speech.speaker: Old.
speech.line: Well, I am glad that all things ſort ſo well.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: And ſo am I, being elſe by faith enforc’d
To call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Well daughter, and you gentlewomen all,
Withdraw into a chamber by your ſelues,
And when I ſend for you, come hither mask’d:
The Prince and Claudio promis’d by this howre
To viſit me, you know your office Brother,
You muſt be father to your brothers daughter,
And giue her to young Claudio.

speech.speaker: Old.
speech.line: Which I will doe with confirm’d countenance.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Frier, I muſt intreat your paines, I thinke.

speech.speaker: Frier.
speech.line: To doe what Signior?

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: To binde me, or vndoe me, one of them:
Signior Leonato, truth it is good Signior,
Your neece regards me with an eye of fauour.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: That eye my daughter lent her, ‘tis moſt true.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: And I doe with an eye of loue requite her.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: The ſight whereof I thinke you had from me,
From Claudio, and the Prince, but what’s your will?

speech.speaker: Bened.
speech.line: Your anſwer ſir is Enigmaticall,
But for my will, my will is, your good will
May ſtand with ours, this day to be conioyn’d,
In the ſtate of honourable marriage,
In which (good Frier) I ſhall deſire your helpe.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: My heart is with your liking.

speech.speaker: Frier.
speech.line: And my helpe.

scene.stagedir: Enter Prince and Claudio, with attendants.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Good morrow to this faire aſſembly.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Good morrow Prince, good morrow Claudio:
We heere attend you, are you yet determin’d,
To day to marry with my brothers daughter?

speech.speaker: Claud.
speech.line: Ile hold my minde were ſhe an Ethiope.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Call her forth brother, heres the Frier ready.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Good morrow Benedicke, why what’s the matter?
That you haue ſuch a Februarie face,
So full of froſt, of ſtorme, and clowdineſſe.

speech.speaker: Claud.
speech.line: I thinke he thinkes vpon the ſauage bull:
Tuſh, feare not man, wee’ll tip thy hornes with gold,
And all Europa ſhall reioyce at thee,
As once Europa did at luſty Ioue,
When he would play the noble beaſt in loue.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Bull Ioue ſir, had an amiable low,
And ſome ſuch ſtrange bull leapt your fathers Cow,
A got a Calfe in that ſame noble feat,
Much like to you, for you haue iuſt his bleat.

scene.stagedir: Enter brother, Hero, Beatrice, Margaret, Vrſula.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: For this I owe you: here comes other recknings.
Which is the Lady I muſt ſeize vpon?

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: This ſame is ſhe, and I doe giue you her.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Why then ſhe’s mine, ſweet let me ſee your face.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: No that you ſhal not, till you take her hand,
Before this Frier, and ſweare to marry her.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Giue me your hand before this holy Frier,
I am your husband if you like of me.

speech.speaker: Hero.
speech.line: And when I liu’d I was your other wife,
And when you lou’d, you were my other husband.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Another Hero?

speech.speaker: Hero.
speech.line: Nothing certainer.
One Hero died, but I doe liue,
And ſurely as I liue, I am a maid.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: The former Hero, Hero that is dead.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Shee died my Lord, but whiles her ſlander liu’d.

speech.speaker: Frier.
speech.line: All this amazement can I qualifie,
When after that the holy rites are ended,
Ile tell you largely of faire Heroes death:
Meane time let wonder ſeeme familiar,
And to the chappell let vs preſently.

speech.speaker: Ben.
speech.line: Soft and faire Frier, which is Beatrice?

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: I anſwer to that name, what is your will?

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Doe not you loue me?

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Why no, no more then reaſon.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Why then your Vncle, and the Prince, & Clau-
dio, haue beene deceiued, they ſwore you did.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Doe not you loue mee?

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Troth no, no more then reaſon.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: Why then my Coſin Margaret and Vrſula
Are much deceiu’d, for they did ſweare you did.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: They ſwore you were almost ſicke for me.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: They ſwore you were wel-nye dead for me.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: ‘Tis no matter, then you doe not loue me?

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: No truly, but in friendly recompence.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Come Coſin, I am ſure you loue the gentlemá.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: And Ile be ſworne vpon’t, that he loues her,
For heres a paper written in his hand,
A halting ſonnet of his owne pure braine,
Faſhioned to Beatrice.

speech.speaker: Hero.
speech.line: And heeres another,
Writ in my coſins hand, ſtolne from her pocket,
Containing her affeƈtion vnto Benedicke.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: A miracle, here’s our owne hands againſt our
hearts: come I will haue thee, but by this light I take
thee for pittie.

speech.speaker: Beat.
speech.line: I would not denie you, but by this good day, I
yeeld vpon great perſwaſion, & partly to ſaue your life,
for I was told, you were in a conſumption.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Peace I will ſtop your mouth.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: How doſt thou Benedicke the married man?

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Ile tell thee what Prince: a Colledge of witte-
crackers cannot flout mee out of my humour, doſt thou
think I care for a Satyre or an Epigram? no, if a man will
be beaten with braines, a ſhall weare nothing handſome
about him: in briefe, ſince I do purpoſe to marry, I will
thinke nothing to any purpoſe that the world can ſay a-
gainſt it, and therefore neuer flout at me, for I haue ſaid
againſt it: for man is a giddy thing, and this is my con-
cluſion: for thy part Claudio, I did thinke to haue beaten
thee, but in that thou art like to be my kinſman, liue vn-
bruis’d, and loue my couſin.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: I had well hop’d ý wouldſt haue denied Beatrice, ý
I might haue cudgel’d thee out of thy ſingle life, to make
thee a double dealer, which out of questió thou wilt be,
if my Couſin do not looke exceeding narrowly to thee.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Come, come, we are friends, let’s haue a dance
ere we are married, that we may lighten our own hearts,
and our wiues heeles.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Wee’ll haue dancing afterward.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Firſt, of my word, therfore play muſick. Prince,
thou art ſad, get thee a wife, get thee a wife, there is no
ſtaff more reuerend then one tipt with horn.

speech.speaker: Meſſen.
speech.line: My Lord, your brother Iohn is tane in flight,
And brought with armed men backe to Meſſina.

speech.speaker: Bene.
speech.line: Thinke not on him till to morrow, ile deuiſe
thee braue puniſhments for him: ſtrike vp Pipers.
